Ukraine's would-be prime-minister Timoshenko sold 12 cruise missiles to Iran and China 
 
 
 huh, my friend sent me a link to a very interesting article and after I read it, I understood that most Ukrainian statesmen are criminals and the higher the rank, the more snouty criminal he or she is. this especially has to do with certain ex-prime-minister Yulia Timoshenko who was number two leader of orange revolution in Ukraine a few years ago and now is the leader of the block of Yulia Timoshenko (BYuT) and thinks she has an absolute right to be elected prime-minister again which confers her considerable powers due to peculiarity of Ukraine's constitution. 
 
 so, according to the article, ten years ago Yulia Timoshenko fixed up a sale of 12 Kh-55 cruise missiles to Iran and China that were capable of carrying 200-kiloton nuclear warheads. Of course she was only the coordinator of the deal and got almost 90 percent of the profit which is approximately $18m. The Kh-55s were sold to Iran and China by Ukrainian company Ukroboronexport, the transaction being performed by accomplices of Yulia Timoshenko. By the way, almost all Timoshenko's banders died under tragic circumstances, for example head of Ukroboronexport Valeri Malev died in a car accident in 2002. I think that Timoshenko was guided by a knowledge that dead people keep their heads shut. I can't imagine that this unfeeling woman sits in the parliament and might become a prime-minister of a civilized country! I guess, if she becomes one, something absolutely unimaginable will start to happen in Ukraine.

Folks, how do you like further widening of NATO eastwards, Ukraine example? I see it as a big challenge for core European countries ... France and Germany mainly....and their energy security. 
 Well Ukraine matters a lot for us as a transit country. I guess both her wealth and ours lies in economy based on sound energy supplies. That is exactly the target! I mean I'm absolutely sure Americans are applying intensified effort to pull Ukraine into their NATO just to make feeble Ukraine and its transit territory as leverage to exert pressure on European heavy weights when needed. 
 Do you remember how then USA defence sec Rumsfield put it when France and Germany opposed the idea of starting war in Iraq? He threatened that they "may be left alone with their position in Europe for European centre of NATO has already moved eastwards". The guy put it absolutely plain! He meant Poland and other former communist countries which have really become a thorn in EU side I should say. With Ukraine in NATO it's going to come to the worst. 
 I think the best thing to do now is just to hamper that "Ukraine in American NATO" project till the year of 2007 or 2012 when our military brass plan to construct European system of security free of those bossy Yankees.
 Relating Ukraine....If she's really after EU membership then her tangling with NATO is madness just. IMO Ukraine should stay neutral the longer the better.

Has anybody taught Yuschenko true democracy?
 It's evident he was taught well how to grasp power and he did it brightly but not how to retain it. He seems to be not so much aware as to what how to use it. And when you lack knowledge and idea you rely on force. That's commonly known and it's just the case in Ukraine now. The Ukrainian president is ready to dissolve the parliament and the government and send his mps to prison or to the back of beyond to isolate all those not bowing to him. Is that democracy?!
 It's rather Saakashvili's brazen style of a caveman. And it has nothing to do with European enlightened democracy. I tend to think American advisors working for Condy Rice's agency are no strangers to those "democratic changes" both in Ukraine and Georgia. Both countries are on the verge of war in the result. 
 European involvement is a must now at least in Ukraine, which is the worst case now. PACE did rightly to have voiced severe criticism over Yuschenko's nonconstitutional moves to finish it up with his political opponents in parliament and government. Perhaps some more decisive actions of the sort should follow to make Ukrainian president back to senses. Though I think he's already ruined his career and his immediate retirement would be most preferable scenario for Ukraine to stay peaceful and for Yuschenko to save face.

What is new in Ukraine? Earlier on Friday preliminary results were reported giving 34.37 per cent to Party of Regions, 30.71 per cent to Block of Yulia Timoshenko, 14.15 per cent to Our Ukraine-People's Self-Defense, 5.39 per cent to the Communist Party of Ukraine and 3.96 per cent to Block of Litvin. Now it is time to start forming coalition and decide what parties stay in opposition. Experts predict that Block of Yulia Timoshenko is likely to stay in opposition while winning Party of Regions and Our Ukraine-People's Self-Defense will form a coalition. Well, I'm sure that this course of events should be the most favorable for Ukraine in the whole and president Yushchenko in particular. I say so because I know that Yulia Timoshenko is not the person he should rely on. According to reports of independent monitoring groups, Block of Yulia Timoshenko is not so popular with the Ukrainians and she got her 30.71 per cent of votes only thanks to bribery of members of Central election commission of Ukraine - that's what was asserted by independent monitoring groups that were interviewing the electorate after the polling. That is harsh truth that Timoshenko enjoys the support of Washington and was rising the finances from certain American NGOs to electioneer and bribe members of election commission at the stage of vote tabulation. Besides that, it also became known on Friday that Block of Yulia Timoshenko made attempts to pay-off a number of members of Our Ukraine party and Party of Regions for polling for a candidate of Yulia Timoshenko as a would-be prime minister. No, Yulia Timoshenko is deliberately not a one who should be making Ukraine's politics at all! She is an oligarch and she harbors plans to become president of Ukraine with the help of funds of the West. Howling shame!

Intrigue of Ukraine's election
 I think all Europeans who are following the process of presidential election in Ukraine are now more interested not in the two leaders of the first round, but in the man came in third, that's Sergei Tigipko. 
 It is clear that now he's got to make a difficult choice. On one hand, he may turn back on his electorate and be untrue to his election agenda by joining Timoshenko in the second round expecting that people who voted for him would now vote for Timoshenko (and Timoshenko has already offered to "buy" his voters for premiership and half of ministerial posts, and knowing Timoshenko we may suppose that Timoshenko also offered Tigipko a sweet sum of money for that). 
 On the other hand, Tigipko should rather remain faithful to his voters and stay separate politician. I need to say that during the election campaign 2010 Tigipko managed to make good result. Obviously, he may win presidential election 2015! Unless he gives up to short-run expectation and fails to be stable enough and independent by joining the banners of Timoshenko. I can only wish him make the right choice.
